courses.name: Introduction to Film Study

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to film form (including style and narration), different types of films, and popular approaches to the study of cinema. Topics include: narrative cinema, documentary, avant-garde, genre, authorship, ideology, and representation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Film Study

courses.name: Film Cultures I: Art and Industry

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the practices, theories, and debates surrounding the emergence of cinema through to the development of studio system filmmaking in the first half of the 20th Century. Topics include: film's relation to the other arts, formalist and realist traditions, technological innovations, audiences and reception, and cultural industries.
cmCourseInfo.title: Film Cultures I: Art and Industry

courses.name: Horror Film

cmCourseInfo.description: Horror film as a genre, focusing on three types of international horror: the un-dead, body horror, and the supernatural. The genre's popular appeal, affective power, unique means of producing pleasure, and current global resurgence will be emphasized. Topics include: the aesthetics of gore and violence, technologies of fear, J-Horror, new French extremity, cult fandom and paracinema, and media convergence.
cmCourseInfo.title: Horror Film

courses.name: Science Fiction Film

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is the study of science fiction films in their cultural and political contexts and the genre's narrative and conceptual components. The goal of the course is to familiarize students with science fiction films as popular genre texts, emphasizing the period between 1950 and the present.
cmCourseInfo.title: Science Fiction Film

courses.name: The Business of Film

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines cinema as a commercial enterprise, emphasizing production, distribution, and exhibition and the political economy of North American film culture.  This is a Breadth Category 3 course but has been specially-designed to fulfill the Quantitative Reasoning requirement for Cinema Studies Specialists and Majors.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Business of Film

courses.name: American Popular Film Since 1970

cmCourseInfo.description: The examination of popular American cinema through its social, political, and commercial practices, and through the study of selected popular films from the 1970s to the present.
cmCourseInfo.title: American Popular Film Since 1970

courses.name: Film Cultures II: Politics and Global Media

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines film theory and practice from the 1950s onward, and the impact of media change on earlier film cultures and aesthetics. Topics include: New Wave cinemas, the politicization of theory, spectatorship, counter-cinemas, transnational film and Global Hollywood, and media theory from the analog to the digital.
cmCourseInfo.title: Film Cultures II: Politics and Global Media

courses.name: Genre, Narrative and Narration in Film

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of theoretical-analytical models of film genres, narrative form, and narration. Structuralist, cognitive-neoformalist, and historiographical approaches will be developed. Genres to be studied include: Westerns, musicals, crime films, biography films, gothic and fantastic films, and art cinema.
cmCourseInfo.title: Genre, Narrative and Narration in Film

courses.name: Special Topics in Genre and Modes

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "Contemporary Screen Comedy," and "Eco-cinema: The Nature of Film."
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Genre and Modes

courses.name: Special Topics in Genre and Modes

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: The Global Film Noir: A Transnational Approach

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "Contemporary Screen Comedy," and "Eco-cinema: The Nature of Film."
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Genre and Modes

courses.name: Cult Cinema

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines "cult" and "exploitation" cinema. It examines the growing popularity of cult/exploitation films as an emerging cinematic subculture that valorizes disreputable or "trash" cinema. A number of sub-genres within exploitation film, including teen films, educational/instructional films, sexploitation, and Blaxploitation, will be explored. The social politics of appropriating texts through ironic reading strategies will also be considered.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cult Cinema

courses.name: Screening Race

cmCourseInfo.description: How race functions in cinema. Topics include: the foundational role of racial inscription and its expansion beyond the black/white paradigm, visual ethnography, 'the primitive,' and Orientalism, aboriginal media, the 'Black Atlantic' and Diaspora, Banlieu and exilic film practice and theory, border aesthetics, race and urban space, 'post-race', and the evolving racial imaginary.
cmCourseInfo.title: Screening Race

courses.name: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "History of Cinematography," and "Everyday Life in the Digital Age."
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice

courses.name: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies. Past topics include: "History of Cinematography," and "Everyday Life in the Digital Age."
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Cinema as Social and Cultural Practice

courses.name: Canadian Cinemas

cmCourseInfo.description: History and diversity of Canadian and Qubcois cinemas. Analyses of film and critical frameworks examine how co-productions, multiculturalism, and post-national arguments are re-shaping the production and reception contexts of national cinema. Annual emphasis will be placed on one of the following topics: the emergence of the feature film, Qubcois cinema, documentary, or experimental cinema.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Cinemas

courses.name: Aspects of a National Cinema

cmCourseInfo.description: In-depth treatment of a national cinema. Past courses include: "British Cinema," "Australian and New Zealand Cinema," and "The Other Europe."
cmCourseInfo.title: Aspects of a National Cinema

courses.name: Hungarian Cinema

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines historical trends, influential filmmakers, and social and cultural factors influencing the development of Hungarian cinema, assessing its impact within the context of Eastern Europe and internationally.
cmCourseInfo.title: Hungarian Cinema
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: INI381H1/F (2010) Aspects of a National Cinema: Hungarian Cinema, INI378H1

courses.name: Special Topics in History and Nation

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Now Hear This: Sound in the Cinema

cmCourseInfo.description: Courses in special topics designed for Specialists and Majors in Cinema Studies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in History and Nation

sections.subTitle: The Diary Film: Cinematic Recordings of the Everyday

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students must complete CIN105Y1, CIN201Y1, and CIN301Y1 before taking any fourth year Cinema Studies course. For ‘E’ Enrolment Indicator Cinema Studies courses: contact the Undergraduate Assistant at 416-978-8571 or cinema.studies@utoronto.ca.

Submit applications to the Undergraduate Program Office: Fall 2016 courses, June 1/ Winter 2017 courses, November 1/ Summer 2017 courses, April 1. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
